title: Award Winners Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is proud to present the  Award Winners Exhibition . 
   
 The exhibition will be on view in Finley Gallery from  November 7 through December 1, 2025 , with an opening reception on  Wednesday, November 12, from 2:00–4:00 PM . 
   
 Finley Gallery will showcase a curated selection of works that highlight the artistry, hard work, and commitment of these emerging creators, offering an inspiring glimpse into the diverse ideas and approaches shaping our students’ practices. 
   
 We invite the public to join us for a reception at Finley Gallery on Wednesday, November 12, to celebrate the accomplishments of these talented makers and the bright futures ahead of them. 
   
 Exhibiting artists include: Jelena Wall (Illustration), winner of the Donald and Judy Miller Scholarship, the Cento Amici Scholarship, and the Ina Golub Scholarship Brett Diese (Visual Communication Design), Dean’s Advisory Board Award and Ina Golub Scholarship Bralen Jones (Visual Arts), Richard Carboni Thesis Materials Award Marlena Holston (Visual Arts), Richard Carboni Thesis Materials Award Santiago Arcila (Visual Arts), Richard Carboni Thesis Materials Award Ashley Ortiz (Illustration), Cento Amici Award Sabrina Saroza (Visual Arts and Art Education), Cento Amici Award Camila Garcia (Visual Communication Design), Dean’s Advisory Board Award Giacomo Valerin (Visual Arts), recognized for Outstanding Work in Integrative Studio I Mari Ahmed (Visual Arts), recognized for Outstanding Work in Integrative Studio I Maurice Tobias (Visual Arts), recognized for Outstanding Work in Integrative Studio II Sadie Vizcaino (Visual Arts), recognized for Outstanding Work in Integrative Studio II Kelly Arita (Visual Arts), recognized for Outstanding Work in Integrative Studio II Jivon Batres (Visual Arts), recognized for Outstanding Thesis in Integrative Studio III 
   
 Scholarship Winners Exhibition Finley Gallery, Finley Hall Exhibition dates: November 7–December 1, 2025 Reception: Wednesday, November 12, 2025, 2:00–4:00 PM

title: Bucket's For BuL.L.S
description:
The Brothers of Tau Phi Beta would like to invite you out to our newly founded annual events called Bucket's for BuL.L.S, This is our exciting charity shot competition that brings together participants of any skill level to support the fight against leukemia and lymphoma. This event combines the love of sports with a noble cause, raising funds to advance research, provide patient support, and improve the lives of those affected by these blood cancers. All proceeds will go to our Philanthropy The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.  
 These contests will consist of: 
 3 pt Contest - Each contestant will have three tries to make at least one three pointer.  
 Free Throw Contest - Each contestant will be given five shots and must make at least three of them to win. 
 Timed Around The World - Each contestant will be given a time limit to complete every shot around the world. 
 We will supply our own basketball net and tape for the lines. Each Contestant will receive a monster or monster merchandise of their choosing as a prize.

title: PHAM General Body Meeting: “Exploring Maternal & Child Health”
organization: The Public Health Association at Montclair State University
description:
Guest Speaker:  Dr. Becky Ofrane 
 Want to make a difference in your community? Join(PHAM) for our next general body meeting focused on community service and advocacy through the lens of Maternal & Child Health (MCH). Our guest speaker, Dr. Becky Ofrane, will share her experiences working in MCH and how advocacy, education, and outreach can improve the lives of mothers and children. You’ll learn how you can get involved in public health efforts that promote equity, wellness, and support for families, whether through volunteering, policy work, or community projects. 
 If you’re looking to: 🌿 Earn  community service hours 💬 Learn/be involved about  advocacy and real-world public health work 🤝 Connect with peers who care about making a lasting impact 
 then this event is for you! 
 Come for the conversation, stay for the FREE FOOD!

title: Study Abroad 101
description: Join the Office of International Academic Initiatives to learn about the Study Abroad Opportunities that Montclair State University has to offer. Whether you want to stay as close to home as Pennsylvania or travel as far away as South Korea, Montclair State University has programs for you.

Whether you’re brushing up on bio, chem, physics, or math, our peer tutors are here to help. Our eboard consists of mainly seniors majoring in biology and molecular biology. Bring your notes, questions, and appetite — we’ll bring the snacks and good vibes!

title: Educated Citizenry/Critical Information Literacy Faculty Workshop & Discussion
description:
In this workshop and discussion co-sponsored by the SEEDS Advisory Board and University Libraries, faculty and librarians will share with each other how they define, teach, and assess educated citizenry, information literacy, and critical information literacy.  We will discuss the Educated Citizenry / Critical Information Literacy (CIL)  rubric ; classroom activities that foster student engagement; and ideas for assessing the Educated Citizenry/CIL SEEDS Value. 
 Faculty teaching a course that addresses the Educated Citizenry (Critical Information Literacy) SEEDS Value - or teaching a SEEDS Foundations or Explorations course that includes (critical) information literacy skills as part of its Student Learning Outcomes - are encouraged to participate.  Please bring your laptop, as well as syllabus and assignments/activities for your SEEDS course(s).  
 Light refreshments will be provided. 
 
 Related LibGuide:  Educated Citizenry (Critical Information Literacy) by Bonnie Fong 
 Register Here: https://montclair.libcal.com/event/15397318

title: Art Forum featuring Alex Callender
description:
The Department of Art & Design presents the Fall 2025 Art Forum series. Art Forum is a speaker series featuring artists, designers, art historians, curators, and art critics from around the world presenting their work and ideas in an open forum.   
   
 The next speaker in this engaging series is Alex Callender. Alex Callender is an artist whose practice employs drawing, painting, and installation to trace and remap historical materials, exploring the intersections of race, gender, and capitalism with both criticality and care. She will discuss her art and process, and share insights into her latest work. This talk will be held virtually. 
   
 Callender has held solo exhibitions at ArtYard (NJ), the Center for the Arts at Northeastern University, UMass Contemporary Museum of Art, NYU Gallatin Galleries, island gallery (NY), and Michigan State University’s LookOut Gallery. They have received grants from the Pollock-Krasner Foundation and the Massachusetts Cultural Council and participated in residencies at MacDowell Colony, The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, The Drawing Center’s Open Sessions, Art in Embassies, Vermont Studio Center, Santa Fe Art Institute, Alice Yard (Trinidad), DRAWinternational, and The BAU Institute (France). Callender is an Associate Professor of Art at Smith College. 
   
 Join us online for this speaker series. The event is free and open to the public. Scan the QR code or link to attend.  
   
 📅 Art Forum 
 Monday, 11/24/25  5:20pm-7pm 
 Virtual -  https://montclair.zoom.us/j/97523525923?pwd=Gpq94c3K4YR4OicqxOAH23MbNGOAn3.1

title: Model United Nations Crisis Committee Simulation — Cyberattack on Global Infrastructure
organization: Montclair State University Model United Nations
description: A massive cyberattack has disrupted global communications, finance, and defense networks. Nations must act fast to protect their citizens, restore stability, and uncover the source of the attack. Delegates will work in real time to draft emergency directives, negotiate alliances, and prevent escalation into full-scale conflict. Strategic thinking, diplomacy, and quick action will be key to success.

title: TLC Food & Clothing Drive
description: Join us in giving back this season by supporting students and community members in need. From November 25 at STCT, we will be collecting donations to benefit Rocky’s Closet and the Red Hawk Pantry. Participants are encouraged to donate non-perishable food items, gently used clothing, school supplies, or hygiene products. Every donation counts! Your contribution, big or small, helps ensure that essential resources are accessible to those on campus who need them. Let’s come together to make a positive impact!

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: Award Winners Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is proud to present the  Award Winners Exhibition . 
   
 The exhibition will be on view in Finley Gallery from  November 7 through December 1, 2025 , with an opening reception on  Wednesday, November 12, from 2:00–4:00 PM . 
   
 Finley Gallery will showcase a curated selection of works that highlight the artistry, hard work, and commitment of these emerging creators, offering an inspiring glimpse into the diverse ideas and approaches shaping our students’ practices. 
   
 We invite the public to join us for a reception at Finley Gallery on Wednesday, November 12, to celebrate the accomplishments of these talented makers and the bright futures ahead of them. 
   
 Exhibiting artists include: Jelena Wall (Illustration), winner of the Donald and Judy Miller Scholarship, the Cento Amici Scholarship, and the Ina Golub Scholarship Brett Diese (Visual Communication Design), Dean’s Advisory Board Award and Ina Golub Scholarship Bralen Jones (Visual Arts), Richard Carboni Thesis Materials Award Marlena Holston (Visual Arts), Richard Carboni Thesis Materials Award Santiago Arcila (Visual Arts), Richard Carboni Thesis Materials Award Ashley Ortiz (Illustration), Cento Amici Award Sabrina Saroza (Visual Arts and Art Education), Cento Amici Award Camila Garcia (Visual Communication Design), Dean’s Advisory Board Award Giacomo Valerin (Visual Arts), recognized for Outstanding Work in Integrative Studio I Mari Ahmed (Visual Arts), recognized for Outstanding Work in Integrative Studio I Maurice Tobias (Visual Arts), recognized for Outstanding Work in Integrative Studio II Sadie Vizcaino (Visual Arts), recognized for Outstanding Work in Integrative Studio II Kelly Arita (Visual Arts), recognized for Outstanding Work in Integrative Studio II Jivon Batres (Visual Arts), recognized for Outstanding Thesis in Integrative Studio III 
   
 Scholarship Winners Exhibition Finley Gallery, Finley Hall Exhibition dates: November 7–December 1, 2025 Reception: Wednesday, November 12, 2025, 2:00–4:00 PM

title: Model UN Crisis Committee - Cyberattack on Global Infrastructure
organization: Montclair State University Model United Nations
description: A massive cyberattack has disrupted global communications, finance, and defense networks. Nations must act fast to protect their citizens, restore stability, and uncover the source of the attack. Delegates will work in real time to draft emergency directives, negotiate alliances, and prevent escalation into full-scale conflict. Strategic thinking, diplomacy, and quick action will be key to success.

title: Audiology (AuD) Virtual Information Session
description:
Our  Audiology program  is designed to empower you to excel in multiple roles—clinician, educator, administrator, and researcher. 
 
 As a clinician, you'll be able to identify the hearing health needs of individuals and design, implement and evaluate treatment plans to meet those needs.  
 In education, you'll be equipped to share your knowledge and inspire others in community healthcare settings. 
 As an administrator, you'll learn to lead, innovate, and elevate audiology services across diverse environments. 
 And with a strong foundation in research, you'll be ready to explore new frontiers in audiology, applying cutting-edge insights directly to your practice. 
 
 Join us for a virtual information session November 25 at 7:00 PM (EST)  to become a versatile leader in the dynamic field of audiology, where your impact can resonate for a lifetime.

title: Chess Club SB Meeting!
description:
Ready to test your strategy and have some fun? Join us for our next  online chess club meeting,  a relaxed session where players of all levels can connect, play, and discuss the game we love. 
 We’ll hang out in voice and chat channels, set up matches on free online boards (like Lichess or Chess.com), and talk through openings, tactics, and memorable games.

 Hope to see you there!

title: E PLURIBUS UNUM
description:
The Latin phrase “E pluribus unum” (Out of many, one) is the motto on the Great Seal of the United States. Originally representing the unity of the thirteen colonies forming a single nation, the phrase expanded to encapsulate the idea that we can be a single people with varied backgrounds and histories. In both ways, this motto has often been more aspiration than description. 
 In this final lecture, President Koppell explores what makes us one nation. Is it simply a legal definition, a shared heritage or commitment to a set of ideals? How do we function as a unified nation when the framers fractured power purposely? What are the features of the U.S. that have bonded communities and institutions together in the face of divisive forces? 
 Event is open to all

title: Resumes for Student Business Owners

description:

 Whether you've launched a startup, built a side hustle, or freelanced your way through college, you've gained real-world skills that employers and grad schools are looking for—you just need to know how to showcase them. 
 In this hands-on in-person workshop, you'll learn to: 
 
 Turn your entrepreneurial experience into resume gold 
 Quantify your wins  
 Frame your business skills in ways that make recruiters actually pay attention 
 Avoid common pitfalls that make student entrepreneurs' resumes get overlooked 
 
 Stop underselling your hustle. Walk out with a resume that shows you're not just another candidate—you're someone who makes things happen.

title: Award Winners Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is proud to present the  Award Winners Exhibition . 
   
 The exhibition will be on view in Finley Gallery from  November 7 through December 1, 2025 , with an opening reception on  Wednesday, November 12, from 2:00–4:00 PM . 
   
 Finley Gallery will showcase a curated selection of works that highlight the artistry, hard work, and commitment of these emerging creators, offering an inspiring glimpse into the diverse ideas and approaches shaping our students’ practices. 
   
 We invite the public to join us for a reception at Finley Gallery on Wednesday, November 12, to celebrate the accomplishments of these talented makers and the bright futures ahead of them. 
   
 Exhibiting artists include: Jelena Wall (Illustration), winner of the Donald and Judy Miller Scholarship, the Cento Amici Scholarship, and the Ina Golub Scholarship Brett Diese (Visual Communication Design), Dean’s Advisory Board Award and Ina Golub Scholarship Bralen Jones (Visual Arts), Richard Carboni Thesis Materials Award Marlena Holston (Visual Arts), Richard Carboni Thesis Materials Award Santiago Arcila (Visual Arts), Richard Carboni Thesis Materials Award Ashley Ortiz (Illustration), Cento Amici Award Sabrina Saroza (Visual Arts and Art Education), Cento Amici Award Camila Garcia (Visual Communication Design), Dean’s Advisory Board Award Giacomo Valerin (Visual Arts), recognized for Outstanding Work in Integrative Studio I Mari Ahmed (Visual Arts), recognized for Outstanding Work in Integrative Studio I Maurice Tobias (Visual Arts), recognized for Outstanding Work in Integrative Studio II Sadie Vizcaino (Visual Arts), recognized for Outstanding Work in Integrative Studio II Kelly Arita (Visual Arts), recognized for Outstanding Work in Integrative Studio II Jivon Batres (Visual Arts), recognized for Outstanding Thesis in Integrative Studio III

title: 2026 Class Gift Tabling - Information and Philanthropy Cord Pick-Up
description:
Each year, our graduating class participates in a proud Class Gift tradition where members of the class invest in the University by supporting areas of Montclair State University that are most important to them. We invite the Class of 2026 to come together to show your support! 
 All gifts to Montclair count! Make your gift to any area of campus you feel most passionate about – such as the Emergency Book Fund, The Red Hawk Pantry, your school or college, The Fund for Montclair State or athletic program. 
 Your gift will pay it forward for future Red Hawks and kick-start your philanthropic connection to Montclair. 
 
 Commemorate your class year! Make a gift of at least  $20.26  and you’ll receive your customized philanthropy cord to wear over your commencement robe.  
 For a gift of  $40 , celebrate this milestone with your family, friends and colleagues by having your message displayed on the screen at the Commencement you will be participating in, and receive a customized philanthropy cord. 
 
 How do I get my customized philanthropy cord? 
 Customized philanthropy cords will be available for pick-up: 
 
 Tuesday, October 28 from 1:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Thursday, November 20  from 1:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Tuesday, December 2 from 12:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Bloomfield Campus Graduation Fair: Wednesday, December 10th from 12:00 – 6:00 p.m. in Deacon’s Den, Talbott Hall  (for Bloomfield graduates only) 
 Montclair Campus Graduation Fairs: Thursday, December 11th from 10:00 a.m. – 7:00 p.m. in the Student Center Ballrooms  (for Montclair or Bloomfield graduates)

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: AI Distinguished Speaker Series: Beyond Breakthroughs: Human Creativity, Break-Withs, and the Limits of AI
organization: College of Humanities and Social Sciences (CHSS)
location: Presentation Hall, College of Communication and Media
description:
The College of Humanities and Social Sciences is launching a new AI  Distinguished Speaker Series —a yearlong exploration of how artificial intelligence is reshaping human systems, knowledge, and society. Designed to be inclusive and engaging, the series will bring thought leaders to campus who not only explain emerging technologies but also invite students and the wider community into critical conversations about their impact. By blending expert insight with student-centered formats, the series aims to spark new ways of learning, questioning, and participating in AI’s future. 
 Register to Attend! 
 Beyond Breakthroughs: Human Creativity, Break-Withs, and the Limits of AI,  Julio M. Ottino, PhD 
 Abstract Creativity isn’t just about producing better answers—it’s about asking different questions. This talk explores the anatomy of transformative creativity, distinguishing between  breakthroughs  that extend existing frameworks and  break-withs  that redefine them. While AI excels at combinatorial creativity—searching and optimizing within established possibility spaces—it cannot originate the conceptual ruptures that create new ones. Such “break-withs” demand a uniquely human capacity:  productive confusion , the ability to be puzzled by what others take for granted. Drawing on examples from art, technology, and science, I will outline five principles that underlie creative work. The future of creativity lies in a new model of collaboration—humans who challenge assumptions, tolerate ambiguity, and sense when frameworks must shift, working alongside AI systems that amplify exploration within the new spaces those shifts reveal.  
 Read More

title: Database Research Strategies and Advanced Search Tips
description:
In this workshop, learn some practical ways to increase the effectiveness of your database searches. As databases have become larger, searching has actually become more difficult to do well without knowing more about how these databases are being developed and managed today. We’ll discuss using Boolean searching tools to manipulate search results, how to engage with database thesauri and a controlled vocabulary, linked subject headings, setting up search alerts, and more. A useful workshop for any research-oriented faculty or graduate students, and for those who teach research in their courses. 
 Register Here: https://montclair.libcal.com/event/15766405

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: What Is It Like To Be a Lawyer? An Online Panel
description:
Have you considered becoming a lawyer, but you aren’t sure if it is the right fit for you? 
 
 
 Join us on Zoom to learn about a day in the life of a family lawyer, criminal defense attorney, personal injury attorney, elected official, and more! 
 All students of all majors and minors are welcome to attend! 
 Can't join the whole time?  No problem.  Join us for as long as you can.  Listen to the panel like it's a podcast while you are commuting ( safely  - eyes on the road!) walking, doing chores, and getting anything you need to do done. 
 We will discuss the following questions: 
 
 - How does a lawyer spend their day? 
 - Can lawyers have a work-life balance? 
 - How do I know if a career in law is right for me? 
 - What is it like to go to law school? 
 - ... and you can ask your own questions as well! 
   
 Questions?  Email prelaw@montclair.edu

title: Weekly Wednesday Zoom Check-ins @ 8pm
description:
Weekly meetings Description @ 8pm on Wednesdays 
 Welcome to the  ​ Disability Rights, Education, Activism, & Mentoring   (DREAM)  Group for College Students with  Disabilities and Allies!  We invite and welcome you, (undergraduates, grad students and allies) to a supportive discussion with peers. Whether you would like to just come hang out with us, meet each other, talk about your experiences as students, vent about life or chill and laugh, we can do it all! We can provide each other with community care!  
 If you are coming as an Ally here are a few ways to be an ally to the disabled community: 1) Check your own internalized ableism. 2) Understand that not every disability is visible to you. 3) If you notice inaccessibility, speak up! Advocate for us. 4) Attend events that center disabled voices. 5) If a person in your life has a disability, take the time to learn about it. 6) Make mistakes, apologize, and learn from them. 7) Consume some media (made by disabled people) about disability. 
 Meetings will be held online via Zoom

title: Kinesiology (MS) Virtual Information Session
description:
Take your career to the next level in Kinesiology Looking to pivot your career into the high-growth fields of health, fitness, and wellness? Montclair State University’s  Kinesiology (MS)  can help you make the leap into exciting new roles where you can make a real difference. This program offers two concentrations: 
 
 The  Concentration in Exercise and Sport Science  is designed to cultivate knowledge in specialized and applied areas of exercise physiology and biomechanics. Students may further finetune their study through elective offerings in exercise programming, cardiac rehabilitation, neuromotor physiology, coaching techniques and sport psychology.  
 
 
 The  Concentration in Sport Administration  is designed to cultivate knowledge and skills needed to work in various facets of the sport industry. The program features a strong core in Sport Administration with options to take additional coursework in Athletic Administration (for certified teachers seeking the Supervisory Certificate), Coaching, and Sport Business.  
 
 Register for our virtual information session December 4 at 12:00 PM (EST) . Meet our expert faculty who equip students with key skills to excel professionally.

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: Information Session: Grad Student Journal Article Writing Group
description:
Are you a graduate student working on a journal article for publication? Learn more about the Grad Student Journal Article Writing Group! This writing group will run over 13 weeks during the Spring semester (January 26 - April 24, 2026), with a week off in March. Weekly topics will include: publication venues, selecting a journal, writing your argument, literature review, citation management and more. We will use Wendy Laura Belcher’s  Writing  Your Journal Article in Twelve Weeks  to guide the discussions and work. Register to attend this Zoom information session where we will discuss how the program will run, the expected time commitment, and answer any other questions you may have. Please contact our Graduate Assistant, Emily Cepin, at  cepine1@montclair.edu  with any questions. A limited number of seats are available. If you would like to register for the club without attending an info session, you may do so by completing this  registration form . Sponsored by the Center for Writing Excellence and the University Libraries. 
 Register Here: https://montclair.libcal.com/event/14826432

title: VOCES: A Fireside Conversation with Author Junot Díaz
organization: College of Humanities and Social Sciences (CHSS)
description:
Join us for an unforgettable evening with Pulitzer Prize–winning author Junot Díaz , one of the most influential voices in contemporary American literature. 
 Presented by Latinos of Montclair, this special VOCES event - held in partnership with Montclair State University’s Department of English - invites audiences to reflect on identity, community & our collective futuro in the context of today’s political and social climate. 
 Díaz, best known for  The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao  and  Drown , has reshaped the landscape of storytelling through his exploration of diaspora, belonging, and the 🇩🇴 Dominican American experience. His recent opinion pieces continue to challenge the narratives surrounding American Latinos, sparking necessary dialogue about who we are and where we’re headed. 
 At this exclusive VOCES fireside conversation, Díaz will discuss: 
 
 The intersections of culture, history, and imagination 
 How storytelling shapes identity and belonging 
 The evolving role of Latinos in the American narrative 
 
 The evening will include an audience Q&A and book signing, offering an intimate opportunity to engage directly with one of the defining literary voices of our time. 
 Tickets are REQUIRED and must be purchased in advance .  Montclair State University students, faculty and staff can attend for free, but must reserve a ticket and show their University ID at the door

title: RA+P and Residence Life Coffee House Night
description:
Coffeehouse is our live music event where students can sign up to perform in Russ Lounge. Whether you’re playing, singing, or just coming to hang out, it’s always a great night of creativity and community. 
   
 The goal of the event is to turn Russ Lounge into a performance space that can accommodate an audience, but it’s also a hands-on opportunity to learn how to set up a performance from start to finish. We will be mixing on a Midas M32R, so it's also an opportunity to learn how digital mixers for live audio work. All that prep work culminates in a show featuring Montclair State students from 7 PM to 9:15 PM. We go through the process of setup, performance, and breakdown. IF this interests you, please fill out  this form  for more information on how to join the crew. 
   
 For those interested in performing in the upcoming coffeehouse, we implore you to fill out  this google form , all applicants will receive an email  with the setlist once all responses have been sent out! 
   
 See you soon, stay groovy!! 
   
 All students are welcome, commuters need to be signed in a with a resident following Residence Life guest registration procedures.

title: Educational Leadership (MA) - Fast Track Option Virtual Information Session
description:
Accelerate your path to leadership 
 Our  Fast Track option  for the Educational Leadership (MA) allows students to earn a 36-credit degree and principal and supervisor certification in 14 months while working full-time. This program is completed within a one-year time frame, from summer to summer. 
 New cohorts for the Fast Track Option begin each Summer. Interested applicants should  complete their application for admission by April 1   each year. Join us for a webinar on December 6 at 10:00 AM (EST)   to learn how this fast-track option can propel aspiring leaders and administrators toward their goals.

title: Friends Day: Be a Buddy
description:
Be a Buddy at Friends Day 2025! 
 Volunteer to be a Buddy on  Sunday, December 7  at the Student Recreation Center from 10am-12pm and/or 2-4pm. As a Buddy, you and another MSU student will be paired with a child or young adult with disabilities to go station-to-station, participate in fun activities and crafts, and help them explore and enjoy the space. You can sign up for  one or both sessions , and  community service hours  will be given. 
   
 Want to volunteer with a friend? Great! Buddies can sign up together as long as you’re both MSU students. This year’s theme is Nickelodeon, so get ready for a fun-filled day inspired by your favorite characters and shows. Come make a meaningful impact while having fun!

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Opera Workshop Chamber Opera presents "The Medium"
description:
Montclair State University Opera Workshop Chamber Opera presents The Medium Gian Carlo Menotti, Librettist & Composer 
 Presented with chamber forces, featuring two pianists in place of full orchestra 
 
 Karen Driscoll,  Director William Hobbs & Ginny Stephens,  Pianists & Musical preparation Deborah Caney,  Costume Designer & Coordinator Lucas Pinner,  Scenic Designer Paige Elise Buchanan Stewart,   Livestream Production 
 Alexander Kasser Theater Sunday, December 7 @ 5 PM  Tickets   & 7:30 PM  Tickets   
 Come join us for Gian Carlo Menotti’s hauntingly beautiful opera,  The Medium . 
 A psychological drama filled with mystery, tension, and lyrical intensity,  The Medium   tells the story of Madame Flora, a fraudulent spiritualist whose world unravels when the line between illusion and reality begins to blur. 
 With its gripping music, dramatic characters, and intimate storytelling, this short opera (in an hour) promises to be a powerful theatrical experience you won’t want to miss. 
 SUNG IN ENGLISH 
 Content Advisory:  The Medium contains depictions of séances, alcohol use, psychological distress, the use of a prop firearm and the sound of gunshots.

title: Information Session: Grad Student Journal Article Writing Group
description:
Are you a graduate student working on a journal article for publication? Learn more about the Grad Student Journal Article Writing Group! This writing group will run over 13 weeks during the Spring semester (January 26 - April 24, 2026), with a week off in March. Weekly topics will include: publication venues, selecting a journal, writing your argument, literature review, citation management and more. We will use Wendy Laura Belcher’s  Writing  Your Journal Article in Twelve Weeks  to guide the discussions and work. Register to attend this Zoom information session where we will discuss how the program will run, the expected time commitment, and answer any other questions you may have. Please contact our Graduate Assistant, Emily Cepin, at  cepine1@montclair.edu  with any questions. A limited number of seats are available. If you would like to register for the club without attending an info session, you may do so by completing this  registration form . Sponsored by the Center for Writing Excellence and the University Libraries. 
 Register Here: https://montclair.libcal.com/event/14826437

title: First Gen Drop-In Group
description:
This is a support drop-in group for first generation college students aimed to help ensure that first-gen students are empowered and prepared to reach their full social, professional, and academic potential. Students will have opportunities to build community, empower and support one another through shared experiences with topics that may include, but not limited to, lack of knowledge about college experience/resources, imposter syndrome, financial and family stress, academic struggles and other challenging subject matters. 
 Group Meets: 
 
 First group will be held on September 9, 2025 
 On Tuesdays from 11:30am – 12:30pm in the Health Promotion Drop-In Center 
 
 For more information, contact group leaders Ms. Charisma Jackson, LCSW at  jacksoncha@montclair.edu

title: Strong Start: Marketing 2026
organization: Feliciano Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation
description:
Ready to level up your side hustle or startup idea? This virtual workshop is your crash course in marketing that actually works—no fancy degree or huge budget required. 
 Here's what we'll cover: 
 
 Growing a brand that feels authentic to YOU 
 Building a newsletter audience that actually cares 
 Marketing tactics that work when you're basically broke 
 Creating a content calendar that doesn't eat up all your free time 
 Using data to figure out what's working 
 
 Whether you're selling on Instagram, launching a service, or testing that app idea—this workshop will help you start 2026 with serious momentum.

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: Weekly Wednesday Zoom Check-ins @ 8pm
description:
Weekly meetings Description @ 8pm on Wednesdays 
 Welcome to the  ​ Disability Rights, Education, Activism, & Mentoring   (DREAM)  Group for College Students with  Disabilities and Allies!  We invite and welcome you, (undergraduates, grad students and allies) to a supportive discussion with peers. Whether you would like to just come hang out with us, meet each other, talk about your experiences as students, vent about life or chill and laugh, we can do it all! We can provide each other with community care!  
 If you are coming as an Ally here are a few ways to be an ally to the disabled community: 1) Check your own internalized ableism. 2) Understand that not every disability is visible to you. 3) If you notice inaccessibility, speak up! Advocate for us. 4) Attend events that center disabled voices. 5) If a person in your life has a disability, take the time to learn about it. 6) Make mistakes, apologize, and learn from them. 7) Consume some media (made by disabled people) about disability. 
 Meetings will be held online via Zoom

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: Fireside Chats
description:
Hang out and have casual conversations about anything and everything with other students while enjoying refreshments! Join us on Thursdays from 3:15-4:15pm.  
 What are Fireside Chats: 
 
 A space for students to meet, connect, and have a casual conversation about a given topic, or anything else that feels comfortable for everyone else. It can be about the school climate, student life in general, or your favorite show. All students are welcome!

title: Child Advocacy and Policy (MA) and Child Advocacy (Certificate) Virtual Information Session
description:
Lead Change in Child Advocacy and Policy   When children and families face complex challenges, they need informed, compassionate professionals to stand up, speak out, and shape solutions. If you're ready to turn your commitment into action, we're here to help.  We're hosting a  virtual information session on December 11 at 6:00 PM (EST) . This is a no-pressure, exploratory space to meet our team and determine if our program fits your goals. This session will cover the following programs:  
 
 Online Master of Arts in Child Advocacy and Policy 
 Child Advocacy (Certificate) – Online 
 
 Why Montclair?  Completing the certificate program allows you to transfer all 15 credits towards the Master of Arts in Child Advocacy, in accordance with all related graduate policy.

title: NIRSA + Montclair IM Sports Pickleball Tournament
description:
Think you’ve got what it takes? Bring your A-Game. IM Sports is serving up an Intramural Pickleball Tournament from December 1-11! Grab your paddle, show off your skills, and battle it out on the courts. The Top 2 Winners won’t just claim victory - they’ll score a PAID trip to represent Montclair State University at the NIRSA Regional Pickleball Championships in Hamilton, NJ in January 2026!  
 Don’t miss out! Rally your friends, sign up, and let’s see who will be crowned Montclair’s Pickleball Champion! 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Create or join a team on  IMLeagues.com/Montclairstate  and make payment at  rec.montclair.edu. 
 Fee is $10 per team. 
 Must be registered  before December 1st, 2025. 
 
 Where and When? 
 
 December 1-11, 2025 
 Student Recreation Center Gym

title: Family Science and Human Development PhD Application Webinar
description:
Advance research, shape policy and strengthen families and communities. The  PhD in Family Science and Human Development  at Montclair State University prepares you to become a leader in research, policy and higher education. 
 This 48-credit program takes an interdisciplinary approach, drawing from psychology, sociology, social work, economics, gender studies and biology to understand individuals, families and communities holistically. 
 Register for the virtual information session to learn more!

title: Weekly Wednesday Zoom Check-ins @ 8pm
description:
Weekly meetings Description @ 8pm on Wednesdays 
 Welcome to the  ​ Disability Rights, Education, Activism, & Mentoring   (DREAM)  Group for College Students with  Disabilities and Allies!  We invite and welcome you, (undergraduates, grad students and allies) to a supportive discussion with peers. Whether you would like to just come hang out with us, meet each other, talk about your experiences as students, vent about life or chill and laugh, we can do it all! We can provide each other with community care!  
 If you are coming as an Ally here are a few ways to be an ally to the disabled community: 1) Check your own internalized ableism. 2) Understand that not every disability is visible to you. 3) If you notice inaccessibility, speak up! Advocate for us. 4) Attend events that center disabled voices. 5) If a person in your life has a disability, take the time to learn about it. 6) Make mistakes, apologize, and learn from them. 7) Consume some media (made by disabled people) about disability. 
 Meetings will be held online via Zoom

title: MBA, Dual Degrees, & Graduate Certificates Virtual Information Session
description: Designed for Where You Want to Go Next Montclair’s  MBA programs  are built for professionals who are ready to lead with purpose—and back it up with strategy. Whether you’re climbing higher in your current role or ready to pivot into something new, our flexible, career-focused curriculum will help you build the skills, confidence, and connections to make it happen.  Registration is open for our  virtual information session December 18 at 9:30 AM (EST) . Join us to explore our MBA pathways and find the one that aligns with your goals.

title: Higher Education (MA) Virtual Information Session
description:
Build your career in Higher Education    
 Whether you're already working in  higher ed  or looking to break into the field, our flexible program is designed to meet you where you are - and help you go even further. 
 We're hosting a  virtual information session on December 18  at 6:00 PM . This is a no-pressure, exploratory space to meet our team and determine if our program fits your goals. 
 Our coursework offers a broad focus on administration and leadership, preparing students for a variety of roles in higher education. The curriculum integrates organizational and social science perspectives and explores key administrative and programmatic issues.

title: Isaac Mizrahi: A Holiday Fruitcake
description:
Actor, host, writer, designer, and producer Isaac Mizrahi “belongs to a brassy show business tradition running from Ethel Merman to Harvey Fierstein and including Liza Minnelli,” according to The New York Times. The creative multi-hyphenate’s one-of-a-kind holiday show features an eclectic mix of holiday classics, unexpected musical choices, and signature wit—blending humor, storytelling, and song. Accompanied by his six-piece jazz band, “Mizrahi is the real deal when it comes to cabaret: He’s charming, he sounds great, and he is seriously funny” (TheaterMania). 
 With a post-show holiday celebration including complimentary food and drinks in the lobby following the show!

title: Swipe Out Hunger
description:
As part of Montclair State University’s continuous commitment to eliminate student food insecurity, Auxiliary Services, Gourmet Dining, and the Office of the Dean of Students began investigating the implementation of a meal plan donation program. The goal also included getting the program recognized by the National Swipe Out Hunger network and establishing an ongoing collaboration with them. In January 2020, Montclair State became an official  Swipe Out Hunger Organization  campus partner. The university has once again teamed up with our resident dining provider, Gourmet Dining, to continue with The Swipe Out Hunger program encompassing both campuses, Montclair and Bloomfield, this semester. 
 Every Montclair State University or Bloomfield College student who is enrolled in a block meal plan (excluding unlimited meal plan holders) will be able to designate up to two (2) swipes per semester to the meal donation program. This drive will be active from October 20 until November 22. No additional meal swipes will be accepted after this date for the Fall 2025 semester.  Fill out this form  to make a difference!

title: Chess Club SB Meeting!
description:
Ready to test your strategy and have some fun? Join us for our next  online chess club meeting,  a relaxed session where players of all levels can connect, play, and discuss the game we love. 
 We’ll hang out in voice and chat channels, set up matches on free online boards (like Lichess or Chess.com), and talk through openings, tactics, and memorable games. 
 No need to bring anything! Just hop on Discord and your favorite chess site! For any questions or concerns, please reach out to any of our e-board members, and they'd be happy to answer! 
 Hope to see you there!

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: Magnificent Bird / Book of Travelers | Two Song Cycles written and performed by Gabriel Kahane
description:
Experience two distinct works by acclaimed songwriter and performer Gabriel Kahane in one unforgettable day.  
   
 In this duo of intimate solo musical plays, composer Gabriel Kahane blends songwriting and storytelling for a singular, poignant theatrical event. Book of Travelers recounts the strangers he met on a 9,000-mile train journey through a divided America, and Magnificent Bird chronicles a year he spent entirely off-line, and the unexpected turbulence of living quietly. Performed on alternating nights, these two concept albums offer a relentless self-inquiry, and a searing portrait of a world in flux.  To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesday - Thursday, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM, and show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK. 
   
 Hailed as “one of the finest songwriters of the day” by The New Yorker, Gabriel Kahane is a musician and storyteller whose work spans the theater, club, and concert hall. Highlights of the 2024-25 season include a return to the New York stage in a production at Playwrights Horizons, performances at the Philharmonie de Paris, Wigmore Hall, and the Concertgebouw with fellow composer/performer Caroline Shaw, the premiere of a clarinet concerto for Anthony McGill, a solo debut with the Orchestre National de Lyon, and Kahane’s San Francisco conducting debut in Carla Kihlstedt’s Twenty-six Little Deaths. Kahane's collaborators range from Phoebe Bridgers, Paul Simon, Sufjan Stevens, and Sylvan Esso, to the Danish String Quartet, Roomful of Teeth, and Attacca Quartet. As a writer, he has been published by The New Yorker online and The New York Times; a newsletter and collection of essays on music, literature, and politics can be found at  gabrielkahane.substack.com . 
   
 4:00 pm Magnificent Bird 
 Run Time:  74 minutes, no intermission. 
   
 Magnificent Bird, is an intimate reflection on a year of self-imposed isolation during which the artist set out to write a song every day. With contributions from Andrew Bird, Chris Thile, Amelia Meath (Sylvan Esso), and Pulitzer Prize- winning composer Caroline Shaw, this collection explores the delicate balance between personal introspection and global crises. It’s a vivid musical snapshot of life during a tumultuous period, offering both a personal and universal meditation on modern-day existence. Based on Kahane’s fifth LP. 
   
 7:00 pm - Book of Travelers 
 Run Time:  70 minutes, no intermission 
   
 In Book of Travelers, Gabriel Kahane embarks on a journey across the United States, exploring the intersections of American identity and personal connection through the people he meets along the way. This powerful and emotional piece blends folk, classical, and pop influences to create a nuanced reflection on contemporary life in America. The work is a poignant and intimate exploration of what it means to traverse a country at a crossroads.

title: I AM | Camille A. Brown & Dancers
description:
Five-time Tony nominated choreographer and director Camille A. Brown deepens her explorations of Black joy in Camille A. Brown & Dancers’  I AM . With captivating live and original music,  I AM  launches new queries into the possibilities of imagination—and boldly investigates the future. Inspired by a narrative within HBO’s  Lovecraft Country  and the rhythms of the movie  Drumline , Brown’s 2025 New York Times Critics’ Pick breaks boundaries and “takes her signature interweaving of African diasporic dance forms to new heights.” —  The New York Times 
   
  To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesdays and Thursdays, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM, and show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK.

title: Rent In Concert | Musical in Concert | Produced by AMP Worldwide
description:
Experience the iconic music of  RENT  like never before. In this sweeping symphonic concert produced by AMP Worldwide, a powerhouse ensemble of vocalists and instrumentalists brings Jonathan Larson’s groundbreaking rock musical to life in a sweeping symphonic concert. Featuring the full score—including “Seasons of Love,” “La Vie Bohème,” and “Take Me or Leave Me”—this electrifying performance celebrates the enduring spirit of love, loss, and chosen family. 
   
 Set in New York City’s East Village at the height of the HIV/AIDS crisis,  RENT  follows a group of young artists as they chase their dreams, navigate heartbreak, and fight to live—and love—fully in the moment. Winner of the Tony Award for Best Musical and the Pulitzer Prize for Drama,  RENT  remains a cultural touchstone with music that resonates across generations. 
   
 To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesdays and Thursdays, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM, and show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.

title: Rocky's Closet at Bloomfield College Pop-Up
description:
We welcome all students who would like to add more clothing to their casual or professional wardrobe to our FREE pop-up shop!  XXS to XXL is the range of our sizes . Shop for as much as you want! 
 If you are interested in bringing your own clothing for other students as well, go for it! Be sure that the clothes don’t have holes or stains and are cleaned beforehand. 
 Psst, did I mention...EVERYTHING IS FREE!

title: Denim Day 2026: Mind the Gaps, Move Forward
description:
April is Sexual Assault Awareness Month, and together, we can break the silence.  The Montclair State University Police Department and the Office of Advocacy & Outreach are committed to fostering a campus where survivors feel heard, supported, and empowered.  It starts with believing. It starts with you.  By offering a safe and affirming response to those who disclose gender-based and sexual violence, we can create lasting change. Let’s stand together to end the cycle of silence—because  every voice matters, and every action counts. 
 Denim Day is recognized internationally as a day of action and awareness, encouraging people to wear denim to challenge victim-blaming and educate others about sexual violence.  This year, Denim Day falls on Wednesday, April 29, 2026. 
 The University Police and  Office of Advocacy & Outreach and the Office of Advocacy and Community Resilience , in partnership with over 30 campus and local community organizations, invites you to join us  from 9 a.m. to 12 p.m. at the Amphitheater  for a powerful awareness event honoring survivors and increasing awareness of available resources. 
 Despite the  gaps  that still exist in the criminal justice system, in resources, and in prevention education,  we will move forward together  as a community. As part of this commitment, we will walk  one mile around campus in solidarity with survivors.
